titleText.ttltext: Cost Effectiveness of Human Papillomavirus @hit_startVaccination@hit_end for Men Who have Sex with Men; Reviewing the Available Evidence

organizations: Unit of PharmacoTherapy, -Epidemiology & -Economics (PTE2), Department of Pharmacy, University of Groningen

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018, Springer International Publishing AG, part of Springer Nature.
paras: Background: Men who have sex with men require special attention for human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end given elevated infection risks and the development of, in particular, @hit_startanal@hit_end cancer. Objective: Our purpose was to review the cost effectiveness of human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end for both currently @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-eligible@hit_end and non-eligible individuals, particularly the men-who-have-sex-with-men population, and synthesize the available evidence. Methods: We systematically searched for published articles in two main databases (@hit_startPubMed@hit_end and @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end). Screening and data extraction were performed by two independent reviewers. The risk of bias was assessed using a validated instrument (Bias in Economic Evaluation, ECOBIAS). Methodological aspects, study results, and sensitivity @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were extracted and synthesized to generate a consistent overview of the cost effectiveness of human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in the men-who-have-sex-with-men population. Results: From 770 identified articles, four met the inclusion criteria. Across the studies, human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end showed incremental cost-effectiveness ratios ranging from dominant to US$96,146 and US$14,000 to US$18,200 for tertiary prevention and primary prevention, respectively. The incremental cost-effectiveness ratio seemed most sensitive to @hit_startvaccine@hit_end efficacy, @hit_startvaccine@hit_end costs, and the incidence of @hit_startanal@hit_end cancer in the selected target populations. Conclusion: This review presents the human papillomavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, both as a primary and adjuvant (tertiary) @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, as a potentially cost-effective strategy for preventing mainly—but not limited to only—@hit_startanal@hit_end cancer in men-who-have-sex-with-men populations.

titleText.ttltext: Treatment efficacy for idiopathic recurrent pregnancy loss – a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end

organizations: Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Skåne University Hospital, Lund University

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 Nordic Federation of Societies of Obstetrics and Gynecology
paras: Introduction: Medical treatment of women with idiopathic recurrent pregnancy loss is controversial. The objective was to assess the effects of different treatments on live birth rates and complications in women with unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss. Material and methods: We searched @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end and the @hit_startCochrane@hit_end Library, and identified 1415 publications. This @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end included 21 randomized controlled trials regarding acetylsalicylic acid, low-molecular-weight heparin, progesterone, intravenous immunoglobulin or leukocyte immune therapy in women with three or more consecutive miscarriages of unknown cause. The study quality was assessed and data was extracted independently by at least two authors. Results: No significant difference in live birth rate was found when acetylsalicylic acid was compared with low-molecular-weight heparin or with placebo. @hit_startMeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end of low-molecular-weight heparin vs. control found no significant differences in live birth rate [risk ratio (RR) 1.47, 95% CI 0.83–2.61]. Treatment with progesterone starting in the luteal phase seemed effective in increasing live birth rate (RR 1.18, 95% CI 1.09–1.27) but not when started after conception. Intravenous immunoglobulin showed no effect on live birth rate compared with placebo (RR 1.07, 95% CI 0.91–1.26). Paternal @hit_startimmunization@hit_end compared with autologous @hit_startimmunization@hit_end showed a significant difference in outcome (RR 1.8, 95% CI 1.34–2.41), although the studies were small and at high risk of bias. Conclusion: The literature does not allow advice on any specific treatment for idiopathic recurrent pregnancy loss, with the exception of progesterone starting from ovulation. We suggest that any treatment for recurrent pregnancy loss should be used within the context of a randomized controlled trial.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end of clinical and pharmacoeconomic outcomes of the human papillomavirus nonavalent recombinant @hit_startvaccine@hit_end

paras: Introduction/Background: As a prevalent sexually transmitted infection with no current cure, human papillomavirus (HPV) prevention includes @hit_startvaccine@hit_end administration. HPV nonavalent recombinant @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (Gardasil 9; hereafter HPV9v) was recently approved and offers additional seroprotection beyond the previously available quadrivalent and bivalent @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Pharmacists must be knowledgeable of HPV9v when providing @hit_startvaccinerelated@hit_end recommendations. Objective: A comprehensive search and systematic evaluation of all literature pertaining to HPV9v was conducted to assess efficacy, safety, and pharmacoeconomic impact relative to previous HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Methods: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end sought primary @hit_startliterature@hit_end related to HPV9v using a comprehensive search of @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end through Ovid, @hit_startEmbase@hit_end, and International Pharmaceutical Abstracts. Keywords included “Gardasil 9,” “HPV nonavalent,” and similar permutations; results were limited to English. Resultant studies were @hit_startanalyzed@hit_end for efficacy and safety data then stratified by the quality of evidence through a 33-point systematic evaluation of methodology and design (utilizing descriptive statistics). Reported outcome measures include: risk of developing HPV; immunogenicity; adverse events; and cost-effectiveness. Results: The search yielded 134 resultant articles, including 20 relevant clinical or pharmacoeconomic studies. Twelve studies were evaluated for efficacy and safety data; eight studies reported pharmacoeconomic projections. Studies comparing HPV9v to previous formulations demonstrated a similar degree and duration of seroprotection respective of their covered strains but a statistically significant risk reduction of acquiring HPV in favor of HPV9v due to coverage of additional strains. Adverse effects were similar across formulations. HPV9v was found to be cost-effective. Conclusions: Following a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of available @hit_startliterature@hit_end, HPV9v appears efficacious, safe, and cost-effective due to additional strain coverage.

paras: The proceedings contain 10 papers. The topics discussed include: results of a solid organ transplantation quality improvement initiative at a large academic medical center; attitudes and perceptions toward pharmacogenomics education and relevance in pharmacy practice in class of 2017 pharmacy students in New York and New Jersey; assessment of splitting methods for buprenorphine/naloxone sublingual films; evaluation of 24-hour automatic stop order impact on albumin use; pegfilgrastim use at south coast centers for cancer care - an educational opportunity 2017; @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of clinical and pharmacoeconomic outcomes of the human papillomavirus nonavalent recombinant @hit_startvaccine@hit_end; and evaluation of a medication education tool implemented across general medicine, surgery, and cardiology floors.

titleText.ttltext: Exploring the role of oncolytic viruses in hepatobiliary cancers

organizations: Department of Medicine, Banner University Medical Center

paras: The standard of care for early hepatobiliary cancers (HBC) includes surgical resection. Liver transplantations or locoregional therapies are beneficial in early hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) under certain circumstances. Systemic treatments have some benefit in advanced HBC, though long-term prognosis remains poor. We evaluated the role of oncolytic viruses in the treatment of HBCs through a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end. The recombinant vaccinia virus JX-594 improved median survival in patients with local/metastatic HCC more strongly at high dose than at low dose (14.1 vs 6.7 months; p = 0.08) in a Phase II study. A Phase III study with JX-594 and sorafenib in advanced HCC is ongoing. No survival benefit in HCC was seen with two other recombinant adenoviruses (Ad-TK and DL1520). Several preclinical trials using oncolytic viruses in HBC showed promising results, warranting clinical studies.

titleText.ttltext: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of models used in quantitative benefit-risk assessment of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end

organizations: UMR1219, Bordeaux Population Health Research Center

paras: Background: Two @hit_startvaccines@hit_end are currently marketed worldwide to prevent the risk of rotavirus gastroenteritis (RVGE) in children below 5 years. As post-marketing safety studies have indicated a transient increased risk of intussusception (IS) after @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, several modelling of benefit-risk (BR) of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end have been conducted in various settings. Objectives: To provide a comprehensive overview of available quantitative models having assessed the BR balance of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end and to compare their characteristics, modelling approaches and estimates both for benefits and risks. Methods: @hit_startMedline@hit_end, Scopus, and ISI Web of Knowledge databases were systematically searched to identify articles in English language published between January 2006 and December 2017. The search strategy combined 2 key search strings related to the following concepts: BR and rotavirus @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Results: Of 386 potentially relevant publications, a total of 10 peerreviewed articles, using quantitative BR models to assess the BR of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, were retained on the basis of pre-selected criteria. Four studies were performed in low-middle-income countries (LMICs). All the studies used a model with a force of infection assumed to be constant over time (static), did not consider indirect effect of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end (herd @hit_startimmunity@hit_end), considered that individuals did not enter and exit the cohort during the study period (fixed cohort), and considered the population and not individual characteristics (aggregate). Most (6/10) of the models were probabilistic and presented sensitivity/scenario @hit_startanalyses@hit_end (8/10). Depending on the models, for every @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-related@hit_end IS hospitalisation and for one IS-associated death, 190 (Singapore) to 1265 (Brazil) RVGE-associated hospitalisations and 71 (USA) to 615 (158 LMICs) RVGE-associated deaths would be prevented, respectively, by @hit_startvaccination@hit_end. Conclusions: This review showed a favourable BR balance of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in all considered settings. Some differences in terms of model characteristics and/or modelling approaches were noted across studies. Standardizing methods used to quantitatively assess BR of rotavirus @hit_startvaccines@hit_end would allow identifying parameters affecting the BR estimates, especially when comparing areas with different socioeconomic levels.

titleText.ttltext: Estimating incidence of adverse events following @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in observational databases when exposure information is unavailable: A contribution from the advance project

paras: Background: Epidemiological models of diseases and exposures synthesize estimates from disparate sources which may lack data on important parameters such as @hit_startvaccine@hit_end exposure. To model @hit_startvaccination@hit_end risks, estimates of the excess incidence of adverse events following @hit_startimmunization@hit_end are needed. Objectives: To compare methods for estimation of incidence rates (IRs) of adverse events following @hit_startimmunization@hit_end when data on the exposure are unavailable in a certain data source (DS), but available in other DSs. Methods: We estimated IRs of febrile seizures (FS), fever, and persistent crying (PC) in risk periods following acellular pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in general practice (GP) or record linkage DSs in Italy, Denmark, Spain, and the United Kingdom. Risk period IRs were derived by multiplying the baseline (non-risk) period IR for DS i by an incidence rate ratio (IRR) obtained from the @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of IRRs estimated using the self-controlled case series method in DSs other than i.We also derived risk period IRs using two further methods: (1) @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of risk period IRs from DSs other than i and (2) multiplication of the background IR for DS i (including risk and non-risk periods) during the recommended month of age at the dose by the @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyzed@hit_end IRR from DSs other than i. Results: For FS after dose 1, observed, @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyzed@hit_end, from baseline and from background IRs (95% CI) were 4.07 (2.99, 5.42), 0.77 (0.21, 2.81), 1.21 (0.45, 3.26), 0.75 (0.27, 2.05) in a record linkage DS and 0.51 (0.11, 1.50), 1.54 (0.52, 4.61), 0.53 (0.19, 1.52), 0.40 (0.14, 1.21) in a GP DS. For fever, the corresponding IRs in the same DSs were 30.17 (27.09, 33.51), 90.19 (69.60, 130.18), 13.25 (9.54, 18.40), 17.37 (12.51, 24.15) and 90.28 (82.75, 98.31), 66.09 (29.39, 148.61), 34.34 (22.58, 52.24), and 43.15 (28.36, 65.67). Conclusions: For well-captured events in a DS, such as FS in the record linkage DS, derivation of IRs using estimates from DSs lacking data on FS (GP DSs) produced a risk period IR inconsistent with that observed. In a GP DS, observed IRs for symptoms such as fever differed from IRs derived via multiplication by @hit_startmeta@hit_end-IRRs which included record linkage DSs. This shows the importance of studying database heterogeneity before parameter derivation. The similarity of derived IRs using baseline vs background IRs may negate the need to identify a non-risk period when the risk period is short. This study was for system testing and not to inform regulatory/clinical decisions on pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Advance system testing: Feasibility of using a network of health data bases for @hit_startvaccine@hit_end safety studies

paras: Background: The Accelerated Development of @hit_startVaccine@hit_end benefit-risk Collaboration in Europe (ADVANCE) public private collaboration, aims to develop and test a system for rapid benefit-risk monitoring of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end using health care databases in Europe. Objectives: To test the feasibility of the ADVANCE system to generate incidence rates (IRs) of events of interest (EI) associated with whole cell-(wP) and acellular-(aP) pertussis @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, in children prior to their preschool-entry booster, using common protocol and @hit_startanalytics@hit_end. Methods: The study population were children aged 1 month to <6 years, during 2001-2016, in 5 primary care databases (ie, Italy (Pedianet), Spain (SIDIAP & BIFAP) and UK (THIN & RCGP)) and two Danish hospital databases (AUH & SSI). IR of injection site reactions (ISR), fever, somnolence, persistent crying, febrile or afebrile seizure/convulsion, hypotonic-hyporesponsive episode (HHE) were estimated both in outcome specific risk windows following wP and aP @hit_startvaccines@hit_end exposure and in non-risk (baseline) periods (presented below as overall IRs). A self-controlled case series design was used to estimate the dose specific Incidence Rate Ratio (IRR) between aP vs non-risk and wP vs non-risk in each database, when wP data were available. Heterogeneity of individual database estimates were inspected, and results benchmarked where possible, random-effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end were conducted for pooling of the IRR. Results: In a study population of 5.9 Million the database specific overall (ie, risk and non-risk periods) IR per 1000 PY varied between 0.5 and 3.1 for ISR, 8.5-491.0 for fever, 0.01-0.44 for somnolence, 2.4-22.1 for persistent crying, 2.6-14.2 for febrile convulsion, and between 0.2 and 1.5 for HHE. IRs were similar within the primary care databases, but hospital-based databases could not estimate ISR, somnolence, and persistent crying. The IRR showed higher risks for wP compared with aP for febrile convulsions, fever, ISR, persistent crying, and somnolence for 1st dose, except for somnolence 2nd dose and febrile convulsions 3rd dose. The risk of HHE was higher following wP compared with aP. IRR and IR were consistent with available literature and expert feedback, except for IRR of HHE. Conclusions: Within ADVANCE we demonstrated the feasibility of generating @hit_startvaccine@hit_end safety data in a public private collaboration of a distributed health care database network. This study was for system testing and not to inform regulatory/clinical decisions on pertussis @hit_startvaccination@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: Safety of newly adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end among older adults, a @hit_startsystematic literature review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: P95, Epidemiology and Pharmacovigilance Consulting and Services

paras: Background: New adjuvants have been developed to improve the efficacy of @hit_startvaccines@hit_end and for dose-sparing and may overcome immunosenescence in the elderly. Objectives: We reviewed the safety of newly adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end in older adults (≥50 years). Methods: We searched @hit_startMedline@hit_end for clinical trials (CTs) including new adjuvant systems (AS01, AS02, AS03, or MF59), used in older adults, published between 01/1995 and 09/2017. Safety outcomes were serious adverse events (SAEs), solicited local and general AEs (reactogenicity), unsolicited AEs, and potentially immune-mediated diseases (pIMDs). Standard random effects @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end were conducted by type of safety event and adjuvant type, reporting relative risks (RR) with 95% confidence intervals (95% CI). Results: We identified 1040 publications, from which we selected 7, 7, and 12 CTs on AS01/AS02, AS03, and MF59, respectively. Among a total of 92 123 study participants, 47 602 received adjuvanted @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and 44 521 control @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, or placebo. The majority of subjects (99%) were enrolled in influenza and Zoster @hit_startvaccine@hit_end trials. Rates of SAEs (RR = 0.99, 95% CI = 0.96-1.02), deaths (0.99, 0.92-1.06), and pIMDs (0.94, 0.79-1.1) were comparable in adjuvanted and control groups. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end@hit_start-related@hit_end SAEs occurred in <1% of the subjects in both groups. The reactogenicity of AS01/AS02 and AS03 adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end was higher compared with control @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, whereas MF59-adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end resulted only in more pain. Grade 3 reactogenicity was reported infrequently, with fatigue (RR = 2.48, 95% CI = 1.69-3.64), headache (2.94, 1.24-6.95), and myalgia (2.68, 1.86-3.80) occurring more frequently in adjuvanted groups. Unsolicited AEs occurred slightly more frequently in adjuvanted groups (RR = 1.04, 95% CI = 1.00-1.08). Conclusions: Our @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end showed no increase in SAEs or fatalities following newly adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. Higher rates for local or general solicited AEs were observed for all newly adjuvanted @hit_startvaccines@hit_end, especially those adjuvanted with AS01/AS02 or AS03, but AEs were mostly mild and transient. Our review suggests that the use of new adjuvants in older adults has not led to any safety concerns thus far. Potential limitations are the restriction to CTs performed in healthy older adults, and numbers too small to detect rare events.

titleText.ttltext: The use of case crossover and selfcontrolled case series studies in pharmacoepidemiology: A @hit_startliterature review@hit_end

paras: Background: Case-only study designs like the case-crossover (CCO) and the self-controlled case series (SCCS) design can assess associations of time-varying exposures on risk of acute health events. They use within-person comparisons and therefore better control for nontime varying confounding than conventional designs that rely on comparisons between individuals. Little recent information exists to what extent case-only designs are used in pharmacoepidemiology. Objectives: To evaluate the use of the CCO design and the SCCS design in pharmacoepidemiology. Methods: @hit_startPubMed@hit_end was searched from inception to 09 January 2018 for original pharmacoepidemiologic research using the SCCS or CCO design. Eligible studies assessed pharmacologic exposures-studies on medical procedures or devices were excluded. Citations including abstracts were used for @hit_startanalysis@hit_end. Pharmacological exposures (up to 3 per publication) were classified into 10 groups and outcomes (up to 3 per publication) into 15 groups. Results: The search identified 1968 citations and 322 studies were eligible for inclusion in the review. Over half of the studies (n = 171, 53.1%) used the CCO design, 145 (45.0%) the SCSS design, and 6 (1.9%) used both designs in a single study. The earliest CCO study was from 1995 and the earliest SCCS study from 2001. The number of articles using either design grew from one in 1995 to 42 in 2015, with no apparent further increase in 2016 (37 publications) and 2017 (42 publications). The most common exposures were @hit_startvaccines@hit_end (n = 88, 27.3%-about one-third on influenza) followed by psychoactive agents (n = 68, 20.8%), cardiovascular agents (n = 41, 12.7%) and @hit_startanalgesics@hit_end (n = 23, 7.1%-most on NSAIDs). The SCCS design was used in all but 5 of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end studies (94.0%), whereas the CCO design was used more for other exposures. Fifteen studies (4.7%) assessed drug-drug interactions. Of all studies, the most frequently seen outcome was cardiovascular diseases (n = 53, 16.5%), followed by gastrointestinal/digestive tract events (n = 34, 10.6%) and bone fractures (n = 20, 6.2%). About one quarter of the studies (n = 86, 26.7%) used the CCO or SCCS design together with another study design for validation purposes. Conclusions: CCO and SCCS designs are increasingly used to assess a range of pharmacologic exposures and safety and effectiveness outcomes. @hit_startVaccine@hit_end safety studies almost exclusively use the SCCS design, which can adjust for age and time effects as @hit_startvaccinations@hit_end are usually given at certain ages or seasons.
